section.title: How do I allow other kinds of incoming connections?
section.para: Shorewall includes a collection of macros that can be used to quickly allow or deny services. You can find a list of the macros included in your version of Shorewall using the command ls /usr/share/shorewall/macro.* or at a shell prompt type:
If you wish to enable connections from the Internet to your firewall and you find an appropriate macro in /etc/shorewall/macro.*, the general format of a rule in /etc/shorewall/rules is:
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DEST PORT(S) <macro>(ACCEPT) net $FW

important.para: Be sure to add your rules after the line that reads SECTION NEW.

example.title: You want to run a Web Server and a IMAP Server on your firewall system:
example.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DEST PORT(S) Web(ACCEPT) net $FW IMAP(ACCEPT)net $FW

section.para: You may also choose to code your rules directly without using the pre-defined macros. This will be necessary in the event that there is not a pre-defined macro that meets your requirements. In that case the general format of a rule in /etc/shorewall/rules is:
section.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DEST PORT(S) ACCEPT net $FW <protocol> <port>

example.title: You want to run a Web Server and a IMAP Server on your firewall system:

para.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DESTINATION PROTO DEST PORT(S) ACCEPT net $FW tcp 80 ACCEPT net $FW tcp 143

section.para: If you don't know what port and protocol a particular application uses, see here.

section.title: How do I make the firewall log a message when it disallows an incoming connection?
section.para: Shorewall does not maintain a log itself but rather relies on your system's logging configuration. The following commands rely on knowing where Netfilter messages are logged:

listitem.para: shorewall show log (Displays the last 20 Netfilter log messages)
shorewall logwatch (Polls the log at a settable interval
shorewall dump (Produces an extensive report for inclusion in Shorewall problem reports)

section.para: It is important that these commands work properly because when you encounter connection problems when Shorewall is running, the first thing that you should do is to look at the Netfilter log; with the help of Shorewall FAQ 17, you can usually resolve the problem quickly.
The Netfilter log location is distribution-dependent:

listitem.para: Debian and its derivatives log Netfilter messages to /var/log/kern.log.
Recent SuSE/OpenSuSE releases come preconfigured with syslog-ng and log netfilter messages to /var/log/firewall.
For other distributions, Netfilter messages are most commonly logged to /var/log/messages.

section.para: Modify the LOGFILE setting in /etc/shorewall/shorewall.conf to specify the name of your log.

important.para: The LOGFILE setting does not control where the Netfilter log is maintained -- it simply tells the /sbin/shorewall utility where to find the log.
